headline: Oatmeal Butterscotch Cookies
description: These butterscotch cookies flavored with cinnamon are loaded with butterscotch chips and healthy oats for a chewy cookie that bakes in 10 minutes.
name: Oatmeal Butterscotch Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Beat butter, white sugar, and brown sugar together in a large bowl with an electric mixer until light and fluffy. Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in vanilla.
Stir together flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt in a separate bowl. Gradually add flour mixture to butter mixture and mix until blended. Mix in oats and butterscotch chips until combined.
Drop dough by teaspoonfuls onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
Bake in the preheated oven until the edges begin to brown, 8 to 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Amazing!
I thought they were very good. I only left out the salt as my wife and I deal with high blood pressure but they still turned out great.
These were so easy to make and delicious. I took them on our annual girl's beach trip and everyone loved them.
Delicious! Didn’t make any changes. Baked 375 for 8 min. Took off cookie sheet after about two minutes and cooled on rack.
very crunchy and hard to get of the pan some of them and burnt not favorite. Still very good tasting
Yummy!

These were pretty good but too sweet for my kids (and what kids say that). I would probably cut down on the sugar next time because the butterscotch chips were much sweeter than the semi-sweet chips I usually use for cookies like this.

As another person posted...we made these using 1 cup of butter...but also had a Bob Ross "Happy Accident". My daughter accidentally put in an additional 1/2 cup of flour (total 1 3/4 cups) and the cookies came out much better than using 1 1/4 cups of flour (see photo...the smaller cookies were made using the extra flour). Based on some other comments sounds like you may be able to fix this by refrigerating the batter but we think the extra flour cookies tasted better and there was no additional wait time.
This recipe is easy and the cookies are super delicious. My family loved them so much that I had to make another batch!
They're pretty good cookies :)
This recipe is perfect just the way it was written!!

The perfect cookie, in my mind, has a crisp outside and chewy center. This recipe (with some adjustments) is exactly that! I MADE THEM GLUTEN FREE with fantastic results! Here are the changes I made: I used gfJules all purpose flour (the best hands down!) in the same amount called for in this recipe. I added ½ cup butter flavored Crisco to the butter called for. I also used GF oats, cane sugar, and added the whole bag of butterscotch chips. The rest of the recipe was followed as written. I refrigerated the covered dough for 1+ hours. To bake, I used a 1 tablespoon cookie scoop on Silpat liners, and baked at 350 degrees (my convection oven automatically knocks that down to 325) for 11 minutes. You want to pull them out right as the edges start to hint at turning brown. They will look puffy and under-baked, but they will be perfect. Trust me. Leave them on that hot pan for 5 minutes (set your timer) and then move to a cooling rack. During the initial cool down on the pan, you will see them solidify and continue to darken ever so slightly. This recipe, with my changes, made 70 cookies. Once cooled, they are sturdy enough to pack up without breaking. I will store them in an airtight container on the counter. They are sweet, but not overly so. There is the slightest hint of cinnamon, it’s only a bit of an undertone, but it absolutely takes this cookie to the next level. I wouldn’t add more, but I wouldn’t leave it out.
Delicious

DO NOT USE THIS RECIPE. It has consequential typos/errors that will cause serious problems. Specifically, there is less than a cup of flour in a recipe for 4 dozen cookies? That is not how cookies work. I am confused about how many people gave this recipe good reviews and said that the cookies came out dry.
Fantastic!
I used 1 cup of butter, 11 minutes at 350, cooled on paper. soft on top, chewy in center, crispy on bottoms. I used a 1 Tbsp scoop and got 52 cookies from the recipe.
These are delicious. I cut the recipe in 1/2. I reduced the heat to 350. Do NOT over cook. I did not cook longer than 10 min. Let sit 5 min before removing from pan. So Good!!!

These are great! I've made them many times now. I did use a full cup of butter, added a 1/4 tsp of nutmeg, used 1 cup of butterscotch chips and added about a 1/2 cup of golden raisins. I used a TBS measuring spoon to make them bigger, baked them at 350 for 9.5 minutes and let them cool on the cookie sheet for 5 minutes before moving them to a rack to finish cooling. My husband loves these!
Awesome cookies. Now one of my favorite
Came out amazing. I used almond flour as a sub. It was great. We love these cookies.
These are great cookies. Love the oatmeal and butterscotch together. Yummy

I used gluten free flour..bob's cup for cup.
Also added a sprinkle of redmond's sea salt to top before baking. 
They came out pefect!

I added 1c of butterscotch chips and 1/2 of sweetened dried cranberries, and reduced the white sugar by a half cup to compensate. Still, those chips made it a little sweet for my taste - I might not add them next time!

Followed the recipe exactly as written. Absolutely scrumptious! I’m not a huge fan of butterscotch, but I think these are great! They are nice and crisp with a soft, chewy interior. Definitely would make these again!
I added a bit more butter and my cookies took a little longer to bake. We loved them and I will make them again.
Great cookies! The whole family loved them, but we did make them bigger so we cooked them for 15 minutes at 375 instead of 10.
These cookies were amazing! The only adjustment that I would make would be to add a little more flour.
I set the temperature to 350 and cooked them for 8-9 minutes. Putting them in the fridge for a little bit did seem to help. They turned out just right. Yummy!
Perfect tasting. My only criticism would be the color, but you really can’t change that!

I made this recipe on 6/20/20 in a muffin tin & they were a big hit! I followed the recipe & will make it again. The muffin tin gives the cookies a slight crisp on the bottom & sides while the center & top remain chewy; it's an excellent combination of textures. YUMMY!

Definitely recommend!

Perfect! Just like mama used to make in the 80s. Instead of butter (which is so expensive where I live), I used a storebought blend of 20% butter/80% margarine. I didn't find the dough too crumbly or dry. The hint to leave them on the sheet longer than normal before moving to a cooling rack was helpful. I made decent sized cookies (rolled them in my hands and then smushed into an oval), and in my oven, I cooked them for about 12+ minutes. Took them out when a few started to brown at the edges. Thank you! :) The kids are very grateful for this recipe, too. ;)

I’m a huge fan of butterscotch, and these totally hit the spot!! I have celiac, so I had to use gluten-free flour, but they turned out perfect. I decided to try making freezer dough out of this to keep them on hand to bake a few whenever I want some fresh-baked cookies. I love slightly over baked cookies, and I found that 15 mins at 325 in my toaster oven (straight from the freezer) = perfection!
I followed suggestions of using a full cup of butter, refrigerated the dough and baked on parchment paper on 350 for 9 minutes. Delicious cookies! Soft, chewy and slightly crunchy, Yum!!

I’m not much of a baker but I love the taste of butterscotch so I gave it my best shot. Upon the advice of another reviewer, I used a cup of butter and I’m glad I did. They were super moist. These were made specifically for some my neighbors who had taken ill. They were elated!
Easy! Tastes. Great for Covid 19 days.
Made these exactly as written. They were excellent!

Been using this recipe for a long time, the butterscotch is a nice change to more typical chocolate chip cookies. Friends and families always love them and they are quite versatile. When we want crunchy cookies we make them smaller and thiner, and when we want something chewy we put big dollops of dough onto the sheets. High recommend
Yummy!!!
Husband loves butterscotch and these hit it out of the park! Reminds me of a good breakfast cookie and is also amazing with a dish of ice cream! Great recipe!
Yummy, very crisp and chewy with a wonderful buttery flavor! made per recipe.
very good

Easy unpretentious recipe that makes enough for a good size party or reunion. 

Easily dressed up by dipping the tines of a fork into melted white chocolate and quick-draping rows on cooled cookies.

Not the prettiest cookie but wow do they taste good!
Baked at 350 instead of 375. Be careful not to make them too big or they won't bake properly.

Very disappointed. Especially with all the 4 and 5 star reviews. If you have to add more butter or flour, chill the dough or otherwise tweak the original recipe you shouldn’t be giving it 5 stars. Having said that, these were a total disaster. Intended to serve these for Christmas Eve tomorrow but now have to come up with something else.
Good cookie. Just followed the instructions.
These were nice and the family enjoyed them

These were a big hit! I made a batch per the recipe and they were incredible. Then I made another batch with raisins instead of butterscotch. It was so easy to swap out and the cookies all came out nice and chewy!

Excellent cookie. From time to time- I add orange zest or flavoring to the ingredients. I vaguely remember orange extract instead of vanilla extract was the original flavoring. And I think it pairs PERFECTLY with the butterscotch cchips. Try it-
Oatmeal and butterscotch deliciousness!
This is a great recipe! They are a hit! I changed the butter to one cup and cooked at 350. Perfect!
Made these cookies before and yes recipe same basic to the Nestle bag, but one ingredient missing Orange zest!
So soft and Chewy We love these cookies!
Made it with the kids super fun.
These turned out perfectly with no adjustments. I will definitely make these again!

These were a huge hit!!! I made a few changes that led me to a really yummy cookie: I used bread flour instead of AP, used 1 c. butter, and added a little more cinnamon than suggested (probably closer to 1 tsp.). Definitely adding these to my repertoire!

Ok- I messed up the recipe but it ended up being for the best! I added 1/2 cup each of brown, regular and powdered sugar. I accidentally added the powdered sugar and wasn’t sure how it was going to turn out. I ended up adding 2 cups of flour and a teaspoon of cinnamon and 2 cups of butter. I did up cooking one batch thinking I may have to redo the entire batch. They turned out fantastic and soft. No refrigeration needed. I would definitely make again
Delicious!

I made these gluten free and they were some of the best cookies! They were much thicker than regular flour and where super soft. I used gluten free quick oats, coconut flour and xantham gum. Will definitely be making these again!
Wonderful cookies that are a nice change from chocolate chips.

Make these exactly how the recipe is written and they were excellent! I did bake at 350 only because I had banana bread in the oven already. I tried to take some off the pan while they were hot and they did fall apart a little. They were perfect after cooling for a few minutes
Great, moist cookies! Did not last a day in my house! Will definitely make again.
Worked like a charm in my Kitchen Aid. A complete success at work and at home. I used only one cup of butterscotch because it’s all I had and felt like it was a perfect touch of butterscotch flavor.
I used 1cup butter and also refrigerated the dough for 1 hour before cooking. Cookies turned out amazing they were a hit.
Don't waste your time on this recipe. The cookie spreads flat and doesn't hold together.

I made it as written, except for the baking temp. I baked at 350 degrees for 10 minutes, and they're delish - also super crispy, but I like that. To get them off of the cookie sheet, I had to bake on parchment, otherwise they required a presidential pardon to leave their baking sheet behind.

I made an account just to warn people about these cookies. I have baked 1000 batches of cookies in my life and these are some of the worst. If using a new recipe, I'll come on here, look for a well reviewed one and follow the agreed upon suggestions in the comments. So for this recipe, since I like chewy cookies, I went for the full cup of butter, chilled the dough and did 9 minutes cooking time. I basically had a giant flat cookie in the pan time after time because the amount of butter was way too much. At nine minutes they were not done and required about 5 more minutes. The cookies were very greasy. I didn't see anyone mention the amount of sugar so I went with it against my better judgement, but it is way too much, and I have a major sweet tooth. Butterscotch chips are incredibly sweet as it is, you don't need 1.5 cups of sugar on top of that. I would suggest 1/2 cup white and 1/4 cup brown. This was a waste of ingredients and I urge you not to make them unless you want a sugar-induced headache.
Wasnt exactly what I was looking for it still really good! I would agree on recommending putting it in the fridge before baking. I'd go closer to the 2 hours in there.
No

I added half a box of vanilla pudding mix along with the dry ingredients which adds more flavor and makes the cookies stay really chewy. Sometimes I add 2/3 cup of chocolate chips to a batch to change them up a little bit, which my kids love!

These were a huge success with my boyfriend and his football team! One think I did was substitute in ? cup of emu sweet chocolate chips instead of 100% butterscotch. I refrigerated the dough which helped my cookies not flatten. I suggest watching the cookies for the last 2 mins because each of my batches cooked differently. Also, to know when done look at the bottom corner of the cookies and when they begin to turn brown they’re close to being done! Don’t wait for them to “get golden”... it’s all about the edges to get the perfect and chewy cookie
Turned out really good I added coconut and nuts!
They didn't even get a chance to cool. That good
I followed the recipe exactly and baked for 8 minutes at 375 (Convection Bake setting on my oven). They are yummy!

I had trouble with them spreading flat when I took the first batch out of the oven. I added about a 1/2 cup of flour the rest of the batter and the rest came out fine. Very tasty....my kids are devouring them! Great cookies!
I need to revise this for high altitude in Colorado by decreasing the sugar because the cookies spread too much.
add a full cup of butter

I left off a star because I modified the recipe a teeny bit. I used 1 cup of butter and a teaspoon more flour, the only changes I made. These are delicious! My last pan is in the oven now. I've 'taste tested' a couple and they're wonderful. I did a combination of spoon-drop and rolling 1" inch balls and both worked well. Baked at 375. I'm using two sizes/types cookie sheet, one's the dark, heavy kind, the other smaller and lighter so varied the bake times. And I chilled the dough too. Thanks for the recipe!

I don't like butterscotch, but I had some butterscotch chips and decided to make them for a cookie swap. I took suggestions from the reviews and decreased the sugar, increased the butter to 1 cup, and doubled the cinnamon. They tasted ok, but a little on the sweet side because of too many butterscotch chips.

Turned out great and added 1/2 cup toasted pecans. Baked at 350 for about 11 min. And then let sit on the cookie sheet an additional 5. Know your oven! Moist and chewy with crunch from the pecans. Definitely a keeper and a repeater!

These cookies will be a signature cookie for us ! Light, as I whipped the butter and sugars .I did add the extra butter and used less chips the subtle butter scotch flavor is amazing. This recipe made 90 cookies . Just excellent!
My wife doesn't like oatmeal cookies. She thought these were delicious!
Great did not change a thing.

Since I was a kid, these are one of my very favorite cookies. 
~ Change baking temp to 350
~ Use one cup of butter
~ ADD 1/2 tsp orange extract. 
I know, it sounds odd, but somewhere in the past, my Mom's original recipe from the 1970's called for orange extract, and they are just not as good without it!
Turned out great!! Increased butter to one cup-- baked 8-9 minutes- let cool slightly before taking them off of cookie sheet
Great recipe and loved how they turned out. The only problem was that there was too much sugar so I'll definitely use less next time.

Outstanding cookies! I have been baking for many (MANY!) decades. I have been looking for a 'chip' recipe that uses butter. I almost always put oatmeal in my cookies, and usually use semi-sweet and butterscotch chips combined. 

I tried these with just a couple of tweaks based on comments. I used 1 c. (2 sticks) of butter, and increased the flour to 1 1/2 c. Cookies came off the sheet perfectly (let cool 6 minutes before removing to rack) and held their shape perfectly. 

They are moist and chewy and perfect. I left them out, uncovered on counter to see how they were on day #2 and they had not changed at all. Hurray!!

I recommend Guittard's Butterscotch chips for incredible flavor. Head and shoulders above Nestle's and store brands. Made 3 dozen nice-sized cookies using my medium scoop. Neighbors and SIL raved.

I made this exactly as written and I loved it. To get them off the tray easier I used Pam on the tray before each set of cookies, and gave them about 30 seconds to 1 min before taking them off the sheet. Worked perfect!! Will make them again!!

I don't usually care for butterscotch oatmeal cookies, but these were very yummy! We accidentally added the oatmeal at the same time as everything else, but they all turned fine. Everyone who tried them raved about them :)
I didn't make any changes to the recipe. Everyone enjoyed them. They are a very sweet cookie.
2 words......ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!!!!!
These were awesome, only upped butter to 1 cup.

Great recipe! Made as directed 14 years ago, which deserved 5 stars as is but over the years I've modified slightly.... I add dried cranberries and chocolate chips (sometimes dark chocolate, sometimes white). With white chocolate, they turn out almost too sweet so I cut back a little on the sugar.

I made this verbatim and just loved the taste. Out of the oven, it was crisp on the outside and chewy on the inside. After one day, the cookies got more chewy, so if people like a crispy texture, they may want to bake it longer. I shared this with a group of 7 women, and everyone loved it. This was a hit indeed!

These were tasty little buggers, I did cut back on the butterscotch chips a little bit I find the flavour can become over powering very quickly. Added a bit more vanilla because... Why not?! 
Wil be making them again :)
Delicious!

I did as some other reviewers suggested.. Increased butter to full cup, added some flour, chilled the dough, and lowered the temp to 350.. These cookies came out glorious. I am huge butterscotch fan and my youngest son begged me to make these... Glad I did. Would give thanks to recipe author, however this recipe is straight off of the Nestle butterscotch morsels bag and it's been republished. I give credit where credit is due.

Perfection! I followed another reviewers tip to up the butter to one cup instead of 3/4 and let them completely cool before removing from the cookie sheet and they held together beautifully. They are heavenly.

This recipe was super easy and family loved the cookies. I will definitely make again and as others suggested, increase butter a tad. I did bake them on parchment so there was zero problems with them sticking. Dough is a little crumbly but the extra butter next time should resolve that issue. Thanks Jolene!
Delicious! My batter was sticky but not out of control. I baked mine for 7 minutes at 375 degrees. I also let mine sit on the pan to cool before moving. For me this recipe was great as is.
